content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct.

entries.title: 15.ai
Meta Releases Llama 3.2-and Gives Its AI a Voice
entries.snippet:
Meta announced the release of Llama 3.2, its most advanced open-source artificial intelligence model, now featuring multimodal capabilities such as visual analysis and voice output. The key upgrade enables the AI to understand images and offer feedback, like identifying bird species or editing photos. Llama 3.2 also supports celebrity voice integration—including John Cena, Dame Judi Dench, Awkwafina, and others—and can now run efficiently on mobile devices using ARM chips, enabling AI-powered apps to interact with phones' cameras and screens.

Mark Zuckerberg showcased these capabilities at Meta's Connect event, including Ray-Ban smart glasses offering visual assistance and AI tools for translating languages, dubbing videos, and creating avatars for creators. Over 180 million users already engage with Meta AI weekly, and the new upgrades aim to broaden AI's reach through widely used platforms like Facebook and Instagram.

Llama 3.2’s open-source nature allows developers and companies to customize and run it locally, offering advantages in data privacy and flexibility. Smaller versions of the model (1B and 3B parameters) target mobile use, while larger ones (11B and 90B) serve more powerful applications. This release positions Meta strongly in the growing field of AI agents and multimodal tools.

v.title: You Can Now Use Stephen Hawking's Speech Software for Free
v.snippet: Intel has released the assistive speech software used by Stephen Hawking—called ACAT (Assistive Context-Aware Toolkit)—as a free, open-source platform. Originally developed to enable communication for individuals with disabilities, ACAT lets users input text and control applications via facial muscle movements, using basic PC hardware with a webcam. While it's currently only compatible with Windows PCs and not designed for general consumer use, developers and researchers are encouraged to build on the toolkit, especially by integrating new input methods like proximity sensors, accelerometers, and Intel’s RealSense 3D camera. Intel’s goal in open-sourcing ACAT is to facilitate innovation in assistive technologies, providing developers with a strong foundation instead of building systems from scratch. Although still geared mainly toward developers, early user reports suggest ACAT is relatively easy to install and use. Intel is also working directly with patients and academic institutions to further test and develop the software.

entries.title: Voices of late actors Judy Garland, James Dean, Burt Reynolds, and more used in AI text-to-speech app
entries.snippet:
ElevenLabs, an AI audio company, has launched a new feature called "Iconic Voices" on its Reader App, allowing users to listen to books, articles, and essays narrated by AI-generated voices of late Hollywood legends such as Judy Garland, James Dean, Burt Reynolds, and Laurence Olivier. These voices were developed in collaboration with the celebrities' estates, including Liza Minnelli, who expressed excitement about preserving and expanding her mother Garland’s legacy through this technology.

The voices are exclusive to the Reader App and are intended for personal streaming use only, not for content creation or sharing. The app is currently available on iOS in select countries but will expand globally and to Android soon, alongside multilingual support.

This development comes amid broader debates about the use of AI-generated celebrity voices, highlighted by a recent controversy involving Scarlett Johansson and OpenAI. Johansson accused the company of using a voice similar to hers without consent, raising legal and ethical concerns. The issue of AI in entertainment was also part of SAG-AFTRA negotiations, leading to consent and compensation requirements for digital replicas of performers. Additional voices are expected to be added to the Iconic Voices library in the coming months.
